content.title: Popliteal Artery Entrapment Syndrome (PAES)
content.summary: Anatomic or functional compression of the popliteal artery by surrounding musculotendinous structures, typically affecting young athletic patients.

definitions.definition: Compression of the popliteal artery by abnormal anatomic relationships with the gastrocnemius muscle or popliteus, or by hypertrophied normal muscle (functional PAES).
Entrapment due to embryologic anomaly - aberrant course of popliteal artery or abnormal insertion of medial gastrocnemius (Types I-V).
Entrapment in anatomically normal structures due to hypertrophied muscle, typically in young athletes. Most common type.

key_concepts.explanation: Type I: aberrant medial head of gastrocnemius. Type II: abnormal insertion of medial gastrocnemius. Type III: accessory slip of gastrocnemius. Type IV: popliteus involvement. Type V: popliteal vein involvement. Type VI: functional.
Young patient (typically <30 years), often athletic. Calf claudication with exercise. May progress to thrombosis, aneurysm, or embolization. Symptoms worse with active plantar flexion.
Provocative duplex: decreased flow with active plantar flexion (50% false positive rate). MRI/MRA: gold standard for anatomy. Angiography with provocative maneuvers: confirms dynamic compression.
Myotomy: release of the compressing muscle. Arterial reconstruction: if aneurysm or occlusion (vein graft preferred). Endovascular: generally avoided due to young age and external compression.

evidence.citation: Turnipseed et al., Athletic PAES Series, 2002
evidence.finding: Functional PAES is more common than anatomic types in athletic populations; outcomes excellent with myotomy

evidence.citation: di Marzo et al., Surgical Outcomes, 1997
evidence.finding: 95% patency at 5 years after surgical release with or without arterial reconstruction

clinical_pearls: Consider PAES in young athletes with claudication and no atherosclerotic risk factors
Bilateral involvement in 25-30% - evaluate contralateral leg
Provocative maneuvers have high false positive rate - use MRI for confirmation
Functional PAES is underdiagnosed in active athletes
If thrombosis present, thrombolysis followed by surgical release and reconstruction
learning_objectives: Apply the Whelan classification for PAES types
State surgical treatment principles for PAES
Recognize the importance of bilateral evaluation
content.statement: Popliteal Artery Entrapment Syndrome (PAES) is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Rare-Syndromes that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Popliteal Artery Entrapment Syndrome (PAES) helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Popliteal Artery Entrapment Syndrome (PAES) include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Popliteal Artery Entrapment Syndrome (PAES).

cross_domain_references.context: PAES should be considered in athletes with exertional leg symptoms
